com.intel.icecp.core

Interface Module


  • public interface Module
    Represent a runnable process for processing on the device. A module has the ability to stop its execution by returning from the run(Node, Configuration, Channel, long) block but module control (loadFromClass, start, stop, etc.) should be accomplished by calling the appropriate at the node level.

    Modules are identified using ModuleProperty--the unique name specified in this attribute is used when determining what modules to load from a JAR. Modules that do not have a corresponding ModuleProperty with a unique name will not load correctly.

    Note that the implementor is responsible for setting the state at appropriate times (see Module.State) by publishing to the passed state channel; this is necessary for the managing node and other modules to interact with it correctly. When a module is first loaded, the node will set the initial state to Module.State.LOADED but implementors should set the module state to Module.State.RUNNING soon after entering the run(com.intel.icecp.core.Node, com.intel.icecp.core.misc.Configuration, com.intel.icecp.core.Channel, long)method; the node will set the state to Module.State.STOPPED after it calls stop(StopReason). Likewise, if the module enters an error state, the module itself should publish Module.State.ERROR.

    • Method Detail

      • run

        @Deprecated
default void run(Node node,
                             Configuration moduleConfiguration,
                             Channel<Module.State> moduleStateChannel,
                             long moduleId)
        Deprecated. use run(Node, Attributes) instead; expect this method to be removed by 0.11.* TODO remove this method in 0.11.*
        Start and run the module; a Node will call this method after it has instantiated a module.
        Parameters:
        node - the node instance the module is running on
        moduleConfiguration - the Configuration for this module
        moduleStateChannel - the Channel on which to publish state changes; e.g. moduleStateChannel.publish(State.RUNNING).
        moduleId - the unique identifier for the newly created module instance; this is necessary because a node could run multiple instances of the same module

      • run

        default void run(Node node,
                 Attributes attributes)
        Start and run the module; a Node will call this method after it has instantiated a module. TODO eventually this method will be the only way to run a module; new modules should implement this and not run(Node, Configuration, Channel, long)
        Parameters:
        node - the node instance the module is running on
        attributes - the initially-configured attributes for the module

      • stop

        void stop(Module.StopReason reason)
        Stop the module; because Java has deprecated Thread.stop(), the implementor has the responsibility to safely tear down the module. This means that implementors need to implement their own loop handling so that they exit gracefully from run() if it is still running in a different thread (implementation note: run() will likely be running in one thread and stop() will be called from another, see link below for suggestions on thread-safe ways to exit).

        This method is a command from the managing node to the module instance, there is little reason for the module to call its own stop()--instead, use the node-level Node.modules().stop(StopReason). Modules that do not respond correctly to this command may interfere with correct operation of the node (e.g. rebooting, upgrading, etc.) and may result in undefined behavior.

        Parameters:
        reason - a code indicating the reason this module was stopped
        See Also:
        THI05-J. Do not use Thread.stop() to terminate threads
